items.title: Algoliasearch client cannot be installed via Pipenv
items.body:
- Algolia Client Version: 2.3.0
- Language Version: Python 3.7.7

### Description
Pipenv is a packaging tool that allows to install python package and to handle .lock files. See [this page for more details](https://pipenv-fork.readthedocs.io/en/latest/basics.html)

When trying to install Algolia search client with Pipenv in a clean environment I get the following error:

```bash
antonin@antonin:~/imake/test$ pipenv install algoliasearch
Installing algoliasearch…
Adding algoliasearch to Pipfile's [packages]…
✔ Installation Succeeded 
Pipfile.lock not found, creating…
Locking [dev-packages] dependencies…
Locking [packages] dependencies…
Building requirements...
Resolving dependencies...
✘ Locking Failed! 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/resolver.py", line 807, in <module>
    main()
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/resolver.py", line 803, in main
    parsed.requirements_dir, parsed.packages, parse_only=parsed.parse_only)
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/resolver.py", line 785, in _main
    resolve_packages(pre, clear, verbose, system, write, requirements_dir, packages)
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/resolver.py", line 753, in resolve_packages
    requirements_dir=requirements_dir,
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/resolver.py", line 736, in resolve
    req_dir=requirements_dir
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/utils.py", line 1386, in resolve_deps
    req_dir=req_dir,
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/utils.py", line 1095, in actually_resolve_deps
    resolver.resolve_constraints()
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/utils.py", line 847, in resolve_constraints
    marker = marker_from_specifier(candidate.requires_python)
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/markers.py", line 719, in marker_from_specifier
    for marker_segment in cleanup_pyspecs(spec):
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/markers.py", line 288, in cleanup_pyspecs
    for op_and_version_type, versions in _group_by_op(tuple(specs)):
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/markers.py", line 203, in _group_by_op
    specs = [_get_specs(x) for x in list(specs)]
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/markers.py", line 203, in <listcomp>
    specs = [_get_specs(x) for x in list(specs)]
  File "/home/antonin/.pyenv/versions/3.7.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pipenv/vendor/requirementslib/models/markers.py", line 187, in _get_specs
    for spec in set(specset):
TypeError: 'LegacySpecifier' object is not iterable
``` 
What is expected is that it should install the search client without any errors. 

A coworker of mine (@Afnarel) pointed me in the correct direction by saying that the `setup.cfg` file had [a weird syntax](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/master/setup.cfg#L39). I cloned the repo and made a minor modification on the `python_requires` line ([see the change](https://github.com/Anto59290/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/master/setup.cfg#L39)). By using my repo the package can now be installed with Pipenv without issues.

I know this is probably not an important issue (as the library can still be used/installed via pip) but I believe the fix is pretty simple.

I was also surprised that other tools used for packaging did not raised an error before that and that the error is only visible when using Pipenv to install the library.

As far as I can tell I believe 77a9fd051de255cf930270a29a56560d48b561a0 [introduced the issue](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/commit/77a9fd051de255cf930270a29a56560d48b561a0#diff-380c6a8ebbbce17d55d50ef17d3cf906R37).

Thanks for your time and have a good day.

### Steps To Reproduce
With Pipenv set up (on Python 3.7.7) run `pipenv install algoliasearch` . The installation will fail.

items.title: feat: built-in operations `IncrementFrom` and `IncrementSet`
Multi-Condition Rules feature
items.body:
This feature brings the support for multi-condition rules, which literally
means you can pass multiple conditions to trigger a single rule. The change
is backward-compatible and would ideally be shipped by mid-July or end-of-July
and it's gonna be deployed by June 19th for us to implement.

1. The feature is about exposing a new `conditions` array of rule conditions
in the rule object. The existing `condition` field remains for
backward-compatibility.
2. Also, please update the CTS like so: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/pull/126/files.
3. Mark the `condition` key as deprecated.

items.title: ImportError: No module named typing
items.body:
<!--
Please use this issue tracker only for reporting bugs or feature requests.

If you need support, please use:

- our community forum
  http://discourse.algolia.com

- StackOverflow with the `algolia` tag
  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/algolia

-->

- Algolia Client Version: 2.2.0
- Language Version: Python 2.7.16
- macOS Catalina 10.15.4

### Description

I install my requirements using a `requirements.txt` file that looks like this:

```
requests
pymongo==3.6.1
python-dateutil
algoliasearch>=2.0,<3.0
xmltodict
pytz
```

Install dependencies script:
```
rm -rf vendored/
pip install -t vendored/ -r requirements.txt
```

Then when I try to run my scripts I get an error like this:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 174, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", fname, loader, pkg_name)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/runpy.py", line 72, in _run_code
    exec code in run_globals
  File "/Users/rodrigoreis/Documents/arena-etl/tests/fsau_afl_importer_test.py", line 1, in <module>
    from lib.foxsportsau.afl_importer import AFLImporter
  File "/Users/rodrigoreis/Documents/arena-etl/lib/foxsportsau/afl_importer.py", line 5, in <module>
    import lib.model.persistence as persistence
  File "/Users/rodrigoreis/Documents/arena-etl/lib/model/persistence.py", line 2, in <module>
    import lib.db.algolia as algolia
  File "/Users/rodrigoreis/Documents/arena-etl/lib/db/algolia.py", line 1, in <module>
    from algoliasearch.search_client import SearchClient
  File "/Users/rodrigoreis/Documents/arena-etl/lib/vendored/algoliasearch/search_client.py", line 8, in <module>
    from typing import Optional, Union, List, Iterator
ImportError: No module named typing
```

I've already tried algolia client versions 2.0.1 and 2.0.2 as well.

### Steps To Reproduce
1. With python 2.7.16 install the algolia client
2. import the algolia client
3. run (the error will be displayed)

items.title: Expose rule.consequence.promote.objectIDs string array
items.body:
On top of the existing `objectID` (singular) string field, a new `objectIDs`
(plural) string array field is now be exposed in the `rule.consequence.promote`
Rule object representation. This lets the user easily promote a full group of
objects without letting some priority conflicts to shift some objects at the end
of the promoted object list.

items.title: Accept `enablePersonalization` boolean as a valid setting parameter
items.body:
All API clients currently should accept the `enablePersonalization` boolean
as a valid search parameter, which defaults to `false` when missing. However,
@rayrutjes recently reported that this parameter is also part of the settings
of an index.

The needed change is to expose the `enablePersonalization` boolean as a
valid setting parameter, which defaults to `false` when missing. It still
needs to be accepted as a search parameter as well.

items.title: SearchIndex.replace_all_objects is stuck when using "safe" mode
If available, ensure that Analytics' regions are "us" and "de" (not "eu")
items.body:
We've recently discovered that at least one API client was exposing "eu" as a
valid region for the Analytics client implementation, which is wrong. Only the
following regions are available at the moment to the Analytics client:

 - "us"
 - "de"

items.title: Ensure correcty tying of API key's restrictSources parameter
items.body:
The `restrictSources` of API keys should be typed as:

 - a comma-separated string

This parameter does **not** support array of strings as a valid type.

items.title: Ensure correcty tying of API key's restrictIndices parameter
items.body:
The `restrictIndices` of API keys should be typed as:

 - an array of strings OR
 - a comma-separated string

Both format should be handled at serialization/deserialization time.

items.title: Ensure secured API key param `restrictSources` only accepts string
items.body:
When generating secured API keys, an optional [restrictSources](https://www.algolia.com/doc/api-reference/api-methods/generate-secured-api-key/#method-param-restrictsources)
parameter can be used as a string (such as `"192.168.1.0"` or
`"192.168.1.0/24"`). We discovered that some API clients wrongly accept other
types (such a list of strings, etc.) which is wrong.

Could you make sure that `restrictSources` only accepts string as a valid type
as a secured API keys parameter?

items.title: Ensure correct serialization of searchSynonyms' type query parameter
items.body:
When performing a `index.searchSynonyms()` call, a [`type` query
parameter](https://www.algolia.com/doc/rest-api/search/#method-param-type) can
be passed to restrict the type(s) of synonyms one wants to search for.

@maxiloc reported us that the Java implementation is accepting an array of
strings for this parameter. However, the engine only accepts a comma-separated
string for this. We then need to double check the implementation of the
serialization of this parameter and provide a fix if needed.

items.title: [2.x] Handle `autoGenerateObjectIDIfNotExist` parameter for `replaceAllObjects()` method
items.body:
The `autoGenerateObjectIDIfNotExist` boolean parameter is for now only valid in
the context of the `saveObjects()` method. As pointed out by @julienpa, it would
make sense to also accepts it as a valid parameter of `replaceAllObjects()`.

For backward-compatiblity, let's make sure the default behavior of calling
`replaceAllObjects()` without the `autoGenerateObjectIDIfNotExist` parameter is
still considered as if it was set to `false`.

items.title: [2.x] Support for large API keys
items.body: in #83, I implemented support for large API keys. This was published in version 1.9.2. The latest version of Algolia appears to have removed this functionality. Could it be re-added? Our implementation depends on it.

items.title: feat(API): introducing the Recommendation client
items.body:
## Context

The personalization strategy endpoint will migrate from the Search API to the Recommendation API.

The consequences of the breaking changes are:

- In `search_client` both methods `get_personalization_strategy` and `set_personalization_strategy` **must** be deprecated.
- API Clients have to introduce a new `recommendation` client.

## Recommendation client implementation

### Endpoint

`https://recommendation.{region}.algolia.com` where region can be `us` or `eu`.

Please note that as for the current `analytics_client` the region should be
`settable` when instantiating the client.

### Route

The route will be `/1/strategies/personalization` and support the following HTTP methods `GET`, `POST`, `OPTIONS`.

- `get_personalization_strategy` -> `GET` : `/1/strategies/personalization`
- `set_personalization_strategy` -> `POST` : `/1/strategies/personalization`

### recommendation_client interface

```java
interface recommendation_client {

    function get_personalization_strategy(opts: request_options)
    return get_personalization_strategy_response

    function set_personalization_strategy(set_strategy_request: strategy, opts: request_options)
    return set_personalization_strategy_response
}
```

### Objects

```java
struct set_strategy_request {
    eventsScoring: events_scoring[]
    facetsScroing: facets_scoring[]
    personalizationImpact: int
}
```

```java
struct events_scoring {
    eventName: string
    eventType: string
    score: int
}
```

```java
struct facets_scoring {
    facetName: string
    score: int
}
```

### Responses

```java
struct get_personalization_strategy_response {
    eventsScoring: events_scoring[]
    facetsScroing: facets_scoring[]
    personalizationImpact: int
}
```

```java
struct set_personalization_strategy_response {
    status: int
    message: string
}
```

For more details regarding the implementation please see the [specfication PR.](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/pull/90)

items.title: feat(mcm): new method has_pending_mapping
feat: add enableABTest as SearchParameter
items.body:
**Summary**

Add the enableABTest query-time only parameter. Defaults to true so that A/B tests are applied by default. Can be set to false to disable A/B tests at query time.

`"enableABTest" : true`

items.title: Ensure `searchUserIDs()` accepts `cluster` and not `clusterName` parameter
items.body:
The Algolia documentation was wrongly documenting that the `searchUserIDs()`
method is accepting an optional `clusterName` parameter. Actually, the
parameter can only be passed as `cluster`.

items.title: feat: add method assignUserIDs
items.body:
**TL;DR**: Add method MCM related method -> `assignUserIDs` and update the CTS accordingly.

Actions required:

1. Add method `SearchClient::assignUserIDs` just like is specified here:

*Signature*:
function assign_user_ids(userIDs: []string, clusterName: string, opts: request_options) return created_response

> The `created_response` is the same as assign_user_id.

*Request*:
```json
{
  "method": "POST",
  "url": "/1/clusters/mapping/batch",
  "hostType": "write",
  "body": {
    "cluster": cluster,
    "users": userIDs
  }
}
```

2. Update the CTS as specified here: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/pull/75/files.

Full details: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/issues/69.

items.title: feat: add request options in exists method
items.body: We need to allow passing the `request_options` into the exists method.

items.title: feat: add contextual rules
items.body:
**TL;DR**: The `condition` field on rules is now optional.

Actions required:

- Update the `cts` with the information on : [#71](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/pull/71/files)
- On strongly typed clients, update types in query rules, as the `condition` field in rules is now **optional**

- [Python test suite update](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/pull/450/files)

items.title: Consider dropping Python 3.4
items.body:
We've been currently investigating a Travis build issue with Python 3.4 and `stestr` (one of our dev dependencies). We've managed to fix the issue by using a non-breaking version of the dependency (`<2.5.0`) in this commit https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/commit/d719c7a703ce7daf5fb0d4c91b0615767e1e4941. We've also [reported the issue to `stestr`](https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/issues/264).

However, perhaps the issue can also simply be avoided by stopping to test against Python 3.4 which is a deprecated Python version since March 2019 as per [PEP-429](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0429/).

WDYT @nunomaduro @Ant-hem @chloelbn?

On my end, I would deprecate Python 3.4 to follow the community but also because migrating between Python 3 minor versions is relatively painless.

items.title: New method: GetSecuredApiKeyRemainingValidity
items.body:
## Summary

When a secured API keys expire, search breaks. The current workaround is more complex
than it needs to be. 

The options for developers using Algolia require, at every place where a search
operation is performed, catching an operation error, identify it as a
"ValidUntil" error, then regenerate the API key, and perform the search
operation again.

The idea is to define a method which tells if a `SecuredAPIKey`
is expired or not without making a single call to Algolia's API.

## References

- Specs: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/pull/25

items.title: New Query Rule parameter
items.body:
## Summary

A new field can be used in the `condition` part of a Query Rule. It's called
`alternatives` and currently it's a boolean. However, this parameter may
transform into JSON object in the future, as documented in the specifications,
which means that if the API client is statically-typed, please encapsulate the
boolean value into a new `Alternatives` structure or class with custom
serializer/deserializer to make this change non-breaking when we will have to
implement it. The Go implementation linked bellow is providing such a structure
for instance.

To test this parameter, simply pass the `alternatives=true` into the
`query_edits` rule of the integration test of the CTS, if implemented, as
written in the CTS PR or add it to any query rule in your integration test
otherwise.

## References

 - Specs: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/pull/60
 - Go implementation: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-go/pull/534

items.title: New setting: indexLanguages array of strings
items.body:
## Summary

Implement the new `indexLanguages` setting which is an array of strings.
Currently, only `["ja"]` is supported by the engine. Changes to be made:

 - Add the setting to the Settings structure/class, if any
 - Set the `indexLanguages` field in the settings integration test if the CTS
   is implemented

## References

 - Specs: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs-internal/issues/40
 - Go implementation: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-go/pull/532

items.title: feat: add index exists method
items.body: The spec and tests for this new method are described here: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs/pull/26

items.title: Check or implement timestamp as request_options for Insights API methods
items.body:
## Summary

As per documentation request, all non-`after_search` methods of the
`insights_client` must now accepts an optional timestamp as part of their
`request_options`.

We need to make sure that once psased via `request_options`, timestamp are not
ignored and correctly used within the `event` payloads that are serialized and
sent to the Insights API.

## References

 - [Documentation issue](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-specs/issues/24)
 - [Documentation PR](https://github.com/algolia/doc/pull/3147)

items.title: API Feature - Implement GZIP for POST/PUT
items.body:
The engine is introducing a new feature allowing to optionally compress request
payloads (ie.  POST/PUT body, http or https).

To test it:

Perform a `saveObject` with the content encoded with GZIP.
Don't forget to add: `"Content-Encoding: gzip"` as a header.

We will discuss a specification for a more detailed implementation.
Like adding a `enableGZIP` flag in client's configuration.

Copy index between app will duplicate synonyms.

items.title: Algolia search depends on `typing` which is in Python3.7 standard library
items.body:
<!--
Please use this issue tracker only for reporting bugs or feature requests.

If you need support, please use:

- our community forum
  http://discourse.algolia.com

- StackOverflow with the `algolia` tag
  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/algolia

-->

- Algolia Client Version: 2.0.1
- Language Version: Python 3.7

### Description
When using the algoliasearch library in a python3.7 environment it installs `typing` which causes some sort of conflict with the standard library. 

Because the library is only required with version of Python 3.5 and below can you add that condition to the requirements file?

See this for context on the issue - https://github.com/python/typing/issues/573

This is a solution implemented elsewhere:
https://github.com/MartinoMensio/allennlp/commit/a7d7b8fd2ff1725f546372850d37b7ab43468465

### Steps To Reproduce
In my case this was actually frustrating me. I can reproduce this issue within an AWS python v3.7.3 runtime but not in my local python 3.7.3 runtime.

My steps to reproduce this involved:
Deploying an application with the algoliasearch dependency to the AWS Python 3.7 runtime.
Noting the stack traces pointing to the Algolia library and the typing library:

File "/var/task/typing.py", line 1004, in __new__
self._abc_registry = extra._abc_registry
AttributeError: type object 'Callable' has no attribute '_abc_registry'

I can open a PR for this fix if you think it would be fixed. At the moment I have to run some custom logic not to deploy the typing library with Algolia search.

items.title: Tests display warning `resourceWarning: unclosed`
items.body:
### Description: 



Locally, while running `sync` unit tests the warning `ResourceWarning: unclosed` appears.

How to reproduce: `export TEST_TYPE=sync && python -m unittest tests.features.test_search_index.TestSearchIndex.test_tasks`.

The test will pass, but you will get this warning:
```
/Users/nunomaduro/Algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/tests/features/test_search_index.py:16: ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=10, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('10.0.32.219', 55446), raddr=('192.99.45.219', 443)>   self.index = None
```

### My research so far:

Possibility solutions:
1. `requests` close automatically sessions and this issue it's specific to `unittest`. We should ignore this warning using something like:

```py
import warnings

warnings.filterwarnings(
    'ignore',
    category=ResourceWarning,
    message='ResourceWarning: unclosed'
)
```

2. Provide a `close` method in the requester and call it on the `tearDown` method.

items.title: Fix issue with flaky test test_dns_timeout
items.body:
### Description

To fix this issue, you should understand why this test is not working:

```py
    def test_dns_timeout(self):

        config = SearchConfig(F.get_app_id(), F.get_api_key())

        config.hosts = HostsCollection([
            Host('algolia.biz', 10),
            Host('{}-1.algolianet.com'.format(F.get_app_id())),
            Host('{}-2.algolianet.com'.format(F.get_app_id())),
            Host('{}-3.algolianet.com'.format(F.get_app_id()))
        ])

        client = SearchClient.create_with_config(config)

        start = time.time()

        for i in range(10):
            client.list_indices()

        duration = time.time() - start

        self.assertTrue(
            duration < 10,
            'retries should have taken less than {} but took {}'.format(10, duration)
        )
```

items.title: get_settings returns and object that cannot be used for set_settings, same for export_rules
items.body:
- Algolia Client Version: 1.17.0
- Language Version: Python

### Description
When the user uses the get_settings() method and then tries to pass that same object to set_settings() he gets this error:

algoliasearch.helpers.AlgoliaException: numericAttributesForFiltering parameter should contain an array of string and not a string near line:1 column:300

It appears we are casting the 'null' default/None data type into a string which is not acceptable to the API.  

The same time of error appears when the user tries to export_Rules() for query rules and then send them back to the index.

`algoliasearch.helpers.AlgoliaException: Expecting a boolean (in` consequence.params.automaticFacetFilters[0].disjunctive`

This is because originally disjunctive was set to false, but the API returned the string 'False'.

### Steps To Reproduce
Use get_settings() on an index with default settings for numericAttributesForFiltering and then use the returned object in a set_settings() call

items.title: `Index.is_task_published` broken
items.body:
- Algolia Client Version: 1.17.0
- Language Version: 3.5+

### Description

The method [`Index.is_task_published`](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/master/algoliasearch/index.py#L723-L724
) is completely broken:

1. It throws an exception:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/prod/.virtualenv/perf/lib/python3.5/site-packages/algoliasearch/index.py", line 724, in is_task_published
    return self.client.wait_task(self.index_name, task_id, request_options)
  File "/home/prod/.virtualenv/perf/lib/python3.5/site-packages/algoliasearch/client.py", line 278, in wait_task
    time.sleep(time_before_retry / 1000.0)
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'NoneType' and 'float'
```

... which is probably due to the fact that `request_options` is passed as a positional argument (instead of named) and overrides `time_before_retry`.

2. But anyway its semantics are inconsistent with `Client.is_task_published`. This method is not meant to wait for a task, but return immediately after the first API call.

items.title: createIfNotExists param ignored in batch mode
items.body:
From the support: `?createIfNotExists=false` parameter is ignored by the REST API in batch mode. It works well in non-batch mode.

> The python client lib has another bug, passing the fixed '/batch' url instead of the calculated path variable. See here: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/master/algoliasearch/index.py#L1025 
> (Most probably istead of appending it to the path, probably you should pass it in the params keyword argument).

items.title: objectIDs are not properly url-encoded
items.body:
Reproduction code:
```python
from algoliasearch import algoliasearch
client = algoliasearch.Client('APP_ID', 'WRITE_API_KEY')
index = client.init_index('test')
index.addObject({'objectID':'https://www.google.com/test/url', 'title':'test title'})
```

Outputs:
```shell
{u'objectID': u'https://www.google.com/test/url', u'taskID': 472031267710, u'createdAt': u'2018-02-12T11:24:14.256Z'}
```

This is an issue because when updating objects, the API client will send something like
```
PUT /1/indexes/test/https://www.google.com/test/url
```

... and the API returns a 404 error.

Related discussion: https://algolia.slack.com/archives/C2V6Z0YUQ/p1518271323000068

items.title: requests[security] and the C tool chain
items.body:
Hello!

Algolia has been super fun to learn and start working with.

I had one minor concern regarding the pinned dependency on `requests[security]`.

We're using the client with AWS Lambda which makes C Dependencies a _major_ pain in the butt.

Specifying the security extras on your package is an _excellent_ idea, as it ensures that folks with older/out-of-date Python installations get a nice high quality TLS connection to your servers.

For folks running Modern Pythons™️ this is no longer necessary.

And unfortunately for folks running in AWS Lambda or other environments that make deploying pure python modules/dependencies easy, it's just a pain in the butt to add PyOpenSSL, cffi, and cyptography.

You could consider using [PEP 508](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0508/) [Environment Markers](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0508/#environment-markers) to specify `requests[security]` for ancient Pythons, while letting folks running the good stuff skate away into the server less sunset :)

items.title: Automated testing of algoliasearch-client-python-async on new releases
items.body: It would be great to automatically run the testsuite of [algolia/algoliasearch-client-python-async](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python-async) when we release a new version: this would have avoided the [recent issue](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/pull/301#issuecomment-341087416) that followed #301.

items.title: [2.0] Migrate to PyPi's new release system
items.body:
We are currently uploading new library versions to the legacy pypi.python.org infrastructure using `python setup.py upload`. This is no more recommended as the new infrastructure will [eventually become the only one](https://packaging.python.org/guides/migrating-to-pypi-org/), and as this method of uploading packages is [insecure and now **strongly discouraged**](https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/distributing-packages/#uploading-your-project-to-pypi).

I propose that we update the release procedure to target the new infrastructure and to use the recommended `twine` method, [as done in the django repository](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-django/pull/224/files).

items.title: [2.0] Improve API of `RequestOptions` class
items.body:
I find the new [`RequestOptions` class](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/master/algoliasearch/client.py#L48-L62) not very intuitive nor very safe.

IMHO, having a class is only useful if we are to do some typing/validation. But, in the current form, anything is accepted. Worse, there is no way to tell if some parameter is going to be a header or a URL parameter; instead, it's implicit: known parameters go as headers, others go as URL parameters. This has the following drawbacks:

- Adding an extra header is impossible
- Mistyping a header silently transforms it into a URL parameter without a warning

I would rather recommend the following approach (also used in other API clients):

- Accept two separate dictionaries in the constructor, for headers and URL parameters (basically mirroring the member fields)
- Provide named properties on top of them

items.title: Passing a string as `attributes_to_retrieve` to `get_objects` fails silently
items.body:
`Index.get_objects` accepts an optional argument `attributes_to_retrieve`, which is expected to be an array of strings. But if it's a string, the method accepts it, although the results won't be as expected.

That's because we `join` the string as if it were an array, resulting in joining each character one by one: `','.join('foo,bar')` will result in `'f,o,o,,,b,a,r'`.

We should:

1. Either accept comma-separated strings and pass them unchanged to the API.
2. Or reject strings and enforce arrays.

I personally prefer solution 2, even if it may break backward compatibility. (It will only break cases that are not functional.)

items.title: Read operations should use `is_search=True`
items.body:
`Index.search_rules` does not specify `is_search=True`, which may potentially lead to targeting a different host than the one used for `wait_task`, and thus leading to inconsistent result (e.g. the wait task host says the task is published, but the host targeted by `search_rules` hasn't finished building it).

Note: Other methods may be impacted. => Let's review them. All read operations should use `is_search=True`.

items.title: save_synonym should use `forwardToReplicas` instead of `forwardToSlaves`
items.body:
Following our internal renaming initiative, the `save_synonym` method should have a few minor adjustements. The REST API now accepts `forwardToReplicas` in addition to `forwardToSlaves` when adding synonyms. All the documentation is being updated so it mention `forwardToReplicas`.

The python client should send `forwardToReplicas` instead of `forwardToSlaves`. Internal variables could also be renamed.

items.title: Unit test fail
items.body:
- Clone the current repo (2015-10-20 @ 14:00 GMT - https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/tree/c50a710ad90d8d0257ab4693ffb8a9b69c10af06)
- Setup the ALGOLIA_\* environment variables
- Setup virtualenv and run pip install -r requirements
- Run nosetets
  
  ```
  [...]
  AlgoliaException: Unreachable hosts: {'8IOHDS4YN8-1.algolianet.com': 'Timeout 
  value connect was (1, 30), but it must be an int or float.', '8IOHDS4YN8
  3.algolianet.com': 'Timeout value connect was (5, 50), but it must be an int or 
  float.', '8IOHDS4YN8-2.algolianet.com': 'Timeout value connect was (3, 40), but 
  it must be an int or float.', '8IOHDS4YN8.algolia.net': 'Timeout value connect was 
  (1, 30), but it must be an int or float.'}
  
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Ran 27 tests in 2.459s
  
  FAILED (errors=30)
  ```

The tests are OK with the following change in client.py, but I'm not sure that's the expected behaviour so I'm not submitying any patch here.

Replace

```
    for i, host in enumerate(hosts):
        if i > 1:
            if isinstance(timeout, tuple):
                timeout = (timeout[0] + 2, timeout[1] + 10)
                timeout = timeout[1] + 10
            else:
                timeout += 10
```

By

```
    for i, host in enumerate(hosts):
        timeout = timeout[1] + 10
```

items.title: Bad write retry error with python 2.7.10
Default functions arguments should never be mutable
items.body:
I found some default arguments being empty dicts, which are mutable. This is wrong as you can't be sure that the dicts will really be empty or not.
More details regarding this issue [here](https://pythonconquerstheuniverse.wordpress.com/2012/02/15/mutable-default-arguments/).
What you should do instead to avoid any bug, is initializing your parameters to None and set them to {} in the function in this case.
For instance, you do it [here](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/88d30f8f4f943976e5eb282e98200e76194ade64/algoliasearch/index.py#L426-L427) and [there](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-python/blob/88d30f8f4f943976e5eb282e98200e76194ade64/algoliasearch/index.py#L303).
